content:
I think testcase 5 and validator 5 have a mistake in it, the length of the sequence for order 21 should be 2^21 - 1 = 2575721 and the indexes given are outside of the range.
I managed to pass them both by setting a length of 2^(order+1) - 1 in my code but it doesn't reflect the true length of the sequence.

Just a tought. The puzzle can be solved without using the 'order'. This case could be tested by having couple of test cases, where ending index is larger than the end of 'Sequence'. And maybe, when the starting and ending index are totally outside of the Sequence, require to output 'None'.

I reviewed all existing Community Puzzles and found no dragoncurve problem. There should be no duplication here.
Thanks all reviewers' effort.

I'm pretty proud right now:)

input()
s,e=map(int,input().split())
print(*(1-int('0{:b}'.format(a).rstrip('0')[-2])for a in range(s+1,e+2)),sep='')

Clarified minor stuff, fixed some grammar, and approved.

I really thought there already was a dragoncurve problem in the set, but I couldn't find it. Have I been dreaming all along?

Got feedback about difficulty in solving it by javascript because of limited bit length in integers. I did a js test and confirm that it failed on the largest dataset.

Accordingly I lowered the limit to N<=50
Now my js solution passes without problem.

Let me know if you got any other issues. Thanks.
It makes sense. Added an extra test case that should time out or memory overflow by brute force.

You should change the last test case to 59. 
Otherwise people will pass all the test cases and then fail the last validator. In C++ at least,  a simple "calculate the whole sequence" algorithm is still working at order 20.

After rethinking the puzzle many times people will soon discover this feature about the 'order'. Having the 'order' concept can help explaining the puzzle and provide a starting point to code a trial solution to experiment with. I did think about making tricks on the starting and ending indexes but finally dropped the idea. Adding new validations on indexes I have to add similar test cases. It will make the puzzle look more complex than it should be and divert focus on minor issues. I believe when a sophisticated solution is done such tricks will naturally become no more challenge.
You are right. I amended this test case and validator. Thank you notifying.

I had that same thought when validating.

My personal conclusion at the time was: it's notable, but would make the puzzle significantly more scary, for not too interesting an addition to the solution.

So it stood as is and I didn't even think of mentioning it anymore.

Good to see others think alike :)
